rights_of_access.description: Washington declares that the people do not yield their sovereignty to agencies that serve them, and in delegating authority, do not give public servants the right to decide what is good for the people to know. The people insist on remaining informed to maintain control over government instruments.
rights_of_access.conditions: No conditions - fundamental policy statement
rights_of_access.applies_to: All persons - sovereignty belongs to the people
rights_of_access.implementation_notes: This is one of the most powerful policy statements in any state FOIA law, explicitly asserting popular sovereignty over government secrecy
rights_of_access.request_tips: Cite: 'RCW 42.56.030 declares the people do not give public servants the right to decide what is good for us to know. We insist on remaining informed.'

rights_of_access.description: The Public Records Act must be liberally construed and its exemptions narrowly construed to promote public policy favoring disclosure. When statutory language is ambiguous, interpretation must favor access.
rights_of_access.conditions: Applies to all statutory interpretation
rights_of_access.implementation_notes: Courts must resolve doubts in favor of disclosure - exemptions receive strictest narrow construction
rights_of_access.request_tips: In disputes: 'RCW 42.56.030 mandates liberal construction favoring disclosure. Exemptions must be narrowly construed and cannot defeat the general policy of access.'

rights_of_access.description: Each agency must make available for public inspection and copying all public records unless specifically exempted. This establishes dual rights to both inspect and copy government records.
rights_of_access.conditions: Subject to specific statutory exemptions only
rights_of_access.applies_to: All public records held by state and local agencies
rights_of_access.implementation_notes: Agencies must provide access to both inspection (review) and copying (duplication) - requesters can choose which they need
rights_of_access.request_tips: Assert: 'RCW 42.56.070 requires you to make records available for inspection and copying. Please provide access.'

rights_of_access.description: Each agency must designate a Public Records Officer (PRO) who serves as the primary contact for records requests and is responsible for PRA compliance. All requests must be submitted to the designated PRO.
rights_of_access.conditions: Every agency must have designated PRO
rights_of_access.implementation_notes: The PRO is the centralized point of contact, ensuring consistent request handling and accountability
rights_of_access.request_tips: Direct requests to: 'Please forward to your designated Public Records Officer as required by RCW 42.56.580.' Or request: 'Who is your designated PRO?'

rights_of_access.description: Public Records Officers and elected officials must complete mandatory PRA training within 90 days of designation or election, with refresher training every four years. This ensures personnel understand requester rights.
rights_of_access.conditions: Training within 90 days; refresher every 4 years; must be consistent with AG Model Rules
rights_of_access.applies_to: All PROs and elected officials of governing bodies
rights_of_access.implementation_notes: Well-trained PROs should understand the law and process requests properly, benefiting requesters
rights_of_access.request_tips: If PRO seems uninformed: 'Has your PRO completed the mandatory training required by RCW 42.56.152? I request to speak with someone trained on PRA requirements.'

rights_of_access.description: Each agency must adopt and publish written policies and procedures for public records access, including list of applicable exemptions, fee schedule, and internal review procedures for denials.
rights_of_access.conditions: Must be published and available to requesters
rights_of_access.implementation_notes: Requesters can demand to see the written policy to understand the agency's process
rights_of_access.request_tips: Request: 'RCW 42.56.070 requires written PRA policies. Please provide your agency's published policy, exemption list, and fee schedule.'

rights_of_access.description: Agencies must respond to records requests within 5 business days. Response must either provide records, acknowledge with reasonable time estimate, or deny with legal basis.
rights_of_access.conditions: 5 business days from receipt; substantive response required (not just acknowledgment)
rights_of_access.implementation_notes: Washington's 5-day deadline is one of the fastest in the nation, ensuring quick initial response
rights_of_access.request_tips: After 5 business days: 'RCW 42.56.520 requires response within 5 business days. Today is day [X]. Please provide records, time estimate, or written denial immediately.'

rights_of_access.description: If records cannot be provided within 5 days, agency must provide a reasonable time estimate based on nature and volume of records. Generic 'we're working on it' responses are insufficient.
rights_of_access.conditions: Estimate must be reasonable given circumstances; must provide periodic updates if estimate changes
rights_of_access.applies_to: Complex or voluminous requests requiring extended processing
rights_of_access.implementation_notes: Agencies must give specific dates or timeframes, not vague promises. Requesters can challenge unreasonable estimates.
rights_of_access.request_tips: If delayed: 'RCW 42.56.520 requires reasonable time estimate. Provide specific completion date based on actual processing requirements.'

rights_of_access.description: Agencies must communicate regularly about the status of pending requests, especially when estimates change or delays occur beyond initial estimate.
rights_of_access.conditions: Required when processing extends beyond initial estimate
rights_of_access.implementation_notes: Requesters should not have to chase agencies - agencies must proactively communicate status
rights_of_access.request_tips: If no updates provided: 'RCW 42.56.520 requires regular communication about request status. Please provide update on current processing status.'

rights_of_access.description: Denials must be in writing and cite the specific legal basis for withholding. The denial must identify the specific exemption claimed for each withheld record or portion.
rights_of_access.conditions: Must be in writing; must cite specific exemption statute; must explain application to specific records
rights_of_access.implementation_notes: Generic exemption citations are insufficient - agency must explain how exemption applies to the specific requested records
rights_of_access.request_tips: Demand: 'RCW 42.56.520 requires written denial citing specific legal basis. Please explain how claimed exemption applies to each withheld record.'

rights_of_access.description: Agencies may charge only the actual cost of copying records. Fees must be reasonable and related to actual reproduction expenses, not administrative overhead or profit.
rights_of_access.conditions: Fees must be actual costs; no markup or administrative overhead
rights_of_access.implementation_notes: Standard photocopying typically $0.15 per page in Washington. Electronic copies should be minimal or free.
rights_of_access.request_tips: Challenge excessive fees: 'RCW 42.56 limits fees to actual copying costs. Provide itemized breakdown showing actual reproduction expenses only.'

rights_of_access.description: Agencies cannot charge for the initial agency review to determine whether records are exempt. The first-pass exemption analysis is part of the agency's duty.
rights_of_access.conditions: Initial review is free; subsequent review for extensive redaction may be charged if substantial
rights_of_access.implementation_notes: Agencies cannot charge for basic legal analysis determining if exemptions apply - only extensive redaction work may be charged
rights_of_access.request_tips: If review fees charged: 'RCW 42.56.120 prohibits charging for initial review to determine exemptions. This is part of your statutory duty.'

rights_of_access.description: Agencies must establish and publish written fee schedules showing costs for copying and any allowable fees. This prevents surprise fees and allows requesters to know costs in advance.
rights_of_access.conditions: Fee schedule must be published and available
rights_of_access.implementation_notes: Requesters can demand to see fee schedule before agreeing to pay
rights_of_access.request_tips: Request: 'Please provide your published fee schedule required by RCW 42.56.070 before I agree to pay any fees.'

rights_of_access.description: The definition of 'writing' explicitly includes electronic data, electromagnetic information, and digital formats. Electronic records have identical status to physical records under the PRA.
rights_of_access.conditions: No conditions - electronic records are public records
rights_of_access.implementation_notes: Emails, databases, electronic documents, metadata, system logs - all are 'writings' subject to disclosure
rights_of_access.request_tips: For electronic records: 'RCW 42.56.010 defines writings to include electronic data. These electronic records must be provided with same access as paper.'

rights_of_access.description: Agencies must provide records in the format requested by the requester if the records are readily available in that format. Cannot force requesters to accept different format if requested format exists.
rights_of_access.conditions: Format must be readily available; agency not required to convert or create new formats
rights_of_access.implementation_notes: If agency has data in Excel, you can request Excel. If in native database format, request that. They don't have to convert.
rights_of_access.request_tips: Specify: 'These records are maintained in [format]. RCW 42.56.070 requires provision in requested format if readily available. Please provide in [native format].'

rights_of_access.subcategory: Electronic Cost No More Than Physical
rights_of_access.description: Agencies cannot charge more for electronic copies than they would charge for physical copies. Electronic delivery should generally be lower cost than paper.
rights_of_access.conditions: Electronic fees must be actual costs and cannot exceed physical copy costs
rights_of_access.implementation_notes: Email delivery of PDFs should be free or minimal cost - certainly less than printed and mailed paper copies
rights_of_access.request_tips: Request: 'Please provide electronically via email. RCW 42.56.120 prohibits charging more for electronic than physical copies.'

rights_of_access.description: Agencies cannot condition disclosure on the requester stating the purpose for requesting records or how they will use them. Identity and purpose are irrelevant to access rights.
rights_of_access.conditions: No conditions - purpose is never required
rights_of_access.implementation_notes: Washington explicitly protects requester privacy - you don't have to explain why you want records
rights_of_access.request_tips: If asked for purpose: 'RCW 42.56.210 prohibits conditioning disclosure on purpose statement. I am not required to state why I want these records.'

rights_of_access.description: Agencies cannot withhold records based on the requester's identity. All requesters must be treated equally regardless of who they are, their status, or perceived affiliations.
rights_of_access.conditions: No conditions - identity-neutral access required
rights_of_access.implementation_notes: Cannot deny because requester is critic, opponent, journalist, activist, or any other identity
rights_of_access.request_tips: If identity-based concerns: 'RCW 42.56.070 prohibits withholding based on requester identity. My identity is irrelevant to my access rights.'

rights_of_access.description: Requests may be made in person, by mail, or by email. No specific format is required, though agencies may recommend using agency forms or webpages for convenience.
rights_of_access.conditions: Request must adequately identify records sought
rights_of_access.implementation_notes: Agencies cannot refuse email requests or require use of specific forms - any method is acceptable if records are identifiable
rights_of_access.request_tips: If method challenged: 'RCW 42.56.080 permits requests by mail, email, or in person. This [method] is acceptable.'

rights_of_access.description: When records contain both exempt and non-exempt information, agencies must provide the non-exempt portions after redacting exempt material. Partial exemptions do not justify complete withholding.
rights_of_access.conditions: Segregation must be feasible; exempt portions redacted
rights_of_access.implementation_notes: Agencies must perform redaction analysis and provide maximum disclosure, not take all-or-nothing approach
rights_of_access.request_tips: Assert: 'RCW 42.56.210 requires disclosure of segregable non-exempt portions. Partial exemptions do not justify withholding entire documents.'

rights_of_access.description: Exemptions must be narrowly applied and cannot be used to create blanket withholding. Even with 500+ exemptions in Washington law, each must be specifically applied to particular records.
rights_of_access.conditions: Agency must identify specific exemption and explain specific application
rights_of_access.implementation_notes: Generic citation to broad exemption categories is insufficient - must explain how exemption applies to specific records withheld
rights_of_access.request_tips: Challenge broad claims: 'RCW 42.56.030 requires narrow application of exemptions. Explain specifically how this exemption applies to each withheld document.'

rights_of_access.description: Any person may petition superior court for injunctive or declaratory relief to compel disclosure. Courts have exclusive jurisdiction over PRA enforcement.
rights_of_access.conditions: Must first request records from agency
rights_of_access.applies_to: Any person denied access or receiving inadequate response
rights_of_access.implementation_notes: Washington provides direct court access without requiring administrative appeals - faster path to judicial resolution
rights_of_access.request_tips: If denied: 'RCW 42.56.550 authorizes superior court petition for injunctive relief. I will file if access is not provided.'

rights_of_access.description: Courts may examine records in camera (privately) to determine whether exemptions apply. This allows independent judicial verification of agency exemption claims without public disclosure.
rights_of_access.conditions: Available in PRA enforcement proceedings
rights_of_access.implementation_notes: Judges can independently review records to verify exemption claims, preventing agencies from withholding based solely on their assertions
rights_of_access.request_tips: In litigation: 'Request in camera examination under RCW 42.56.550 to independently verify exemption claims.'

rights_of_access.description: Plaintiffs who substantially prevail in PRA enforcement actions may recover reasonable attorney fees and costs. This makes litigation financially feasible for wronged requesters.
rights_of_access.conditions: Must substantially prevail; fees must be reasonable and necessary
rights_of_access.implementation_notes: Attorney fee recovery is available to substantially prevailing requesters, incentivizing agencies to comply rather than defend improper denials
rights_of_access.request_tips: When considering litigation: 'RCW 42.56.550 provides attorney fee recovery if I substantially prevail. Improper denial will result in you paying my legal costs.'

rights_of_access.description: Courts may impose daily penalties of $5-$100 per day for each record wrongfully withheld, paid to the person seeking disclosure. Penalties calculate from date of violation and continue until compliance.
rights_of_access.conditions: Record must be wrongfully withheld; penalty amount at court discretion ($5-$100/day); may be reduced for good faith
rights_of_access.applies_to: Successful litigants where records were wrongfully withheld
rights_of_access.implementation_notes: Daily penalties create strong incentive for compliance - a 30-day wrongful denial could result in $3,000 penalty to requester
rights_of_access.request_tips: Warn: 'RCW 42.56.565 authorizes daily penalties up to $100/day for wrongful withholding. Each day of improper denial increases potential liability.'

rights_of_access.description: The agency bears the burden of proving that records are exempt from disclosure. Requesters do not have to prove entitlement - agencies must justify denials with specific evidence.
rights_of_access.conditions: Applies in all enforcement proceedings
rights_of_access.applies_to: All denied requests subject to litigation
rights_of_access.implementation_notes: This shifts litigation burden to agency - they must prove exemptions apply with evidence, not just assert them
rights_of_access.request_tips: In disputes: 'Under RCW 42.56.550, you bear burden of proving exemption. Provide specific evidence, not assertions, that exemption applies.'

rights_of_access.description: The Attorney General maintains Model Rules (WAC 44-14) providing detailed practical guidance on PRA compliance. These rules inform training and provide persuasive authority on proper procedures.
rights_of_access.conditions: Model Rules are advisory, not binding, but inform required training
rights_of_access.implementation_notes: Model Rules provide detailed guidance agencies should follow - requesters can cite Model Rules as best practices
rights_of_access.request_tips: Reference guidance: 'The AG Model Rules at WAC 44-14 recommend [cite specific guidance]. Please follow these best practices.'

rights_of_access.description: Agencies must establish internal review procedures for denials, allowing requesters to challenge denials within the agency before resorting to litigation.
rights_of_access.conditions: Must be included in published PRA policy
rights_of_access.implementation_notes: Internal review provides opportunity to resolve disputes without court involvement
rights_of_access.request_tips: If denied: 'Your PRA policy required by RCW 42.56.070 must include internal review procedure. I request administrative review of this denial.'

rights_of_access.description: If a request is unclear or overly broad, agencies must contact the requester to seek clarification rather than simply denying. Requesters have the right to clarify and narrow requests.
rights_of_access.conditions: Agency must attempt clarification before denial for vagueness
rights_of_access.implementation_notes: Agencies cannot deny as 'too broad' without first attempting to work with requester to clarify scope
rights_of_access.request_tips: If denied as vague: 'RCW 42.56.520 requires you to seek clarification before denying. Contact me to discuss clarification rather than denying outright.'

rights_of_access.description: Records are public unless they fall within specific statutory exemptions. General claims of sensitivity or confidentiality without specific exemption authority are insufficient to withhold.
rights_of_access.conditions: Agency must cite specific RCW section creating exemption
rights_of_access.implementation_notes: With 500+ exemptions in Washington law, agencies must identify the exact applicable exemption by statute number
rights_of_access.request_tips: Demand specificity: 'RCW 42.56.070 requires specific statutory exemption. Please cite the exact RCW section authorizing withholding, not general claims of sensitivity.'

rights_of_access.description: Electronic records include associated metadata. Agencies must consider metadata implications when producing electronic records, as metadata is part of the record.
rights_of_access.conditions: Metadata must be part of electronic record production
rights_of_access.implementation_notes: Metadata includes creation dates, author, edit history, etc. - valuable context for electronic records
rights_of_access.request_tips: For electronic records: 'Please preserve and include all associated metadata. RCW 42.56.010 includes metadata as part of electronic writings.'

rights_of_access.description: Agencies must provide facilities for copying records during normal business hours. Cannot restrict access to limited appointment times or create unreasonable barriers.
rights_of_access.conditions: Must be during agency business hours; reasonable scheduling permitted
rights_of_access.applies_to: All in-person inspection and copying requests
rights_of_access.implementation_notes: Agencies must make records reasonably accessible, not impose inconvenient or restrictive access conditions
rights_of_access.request_tips: Request: 'RCW 42.56.070 requires facilities for copying during business hours. Please accommodate reasonable access times.'

rights_of_access.description: Agencies must maintain records indexes if feasible to help requesters identify and locate relevant records. This aids in formulating specific requests.
rights_of_access.conditions: Required if feasible; nature of index varies by agency
rights_of_access.applies_to: All agencies where indexing is feasible
rights_of_access.implementation_notes: Indexes help requesters make targeted requests by revealing what records exist and how they're organized
rights_of_access.request_tips: Ask: 'Do you maintain a records index as contemplated by RCW 42.56.070? An index would help me formulate more specific requests.'

rights_of_access.description: Agencies must track and log all records requests, maintaining records of requests received, responses provided, and fees charged. This creates accountability.
rights_of_access.conditions: Required for all agencies
rights_of_access.implementation_notes: Request logs are themselves public records - requesters can request logs to see how similar requests were handled
rights_of_access.request_tips: Request: 'Please provide your PRA request log showing how similar requests were handled and what fees were charged.'

rights_of_access.description: Washington grants access to 'any person' and 'all persons' without residency, citizenship, or any other qualification. Out-of-state residents, foreign nationals, and anyone may request records.
rights_of_access.conditions: No conditions on residency or citizenship
rights_of_access.applies_to: All persons regardless of connection to Washington
rights_of_access.implementation_notes: Washington uses universal language establishing access as a human right, not limited to residents
rights_of_access.request_tips: If residency questioned: 'RCW 42.56 grants access to any person without residency requirement.'

rights_of_access.description: Agencies cannot create blanket exemptions for entire categories of records. Each exemption must be applied to specific records based on their specific content.
rights_of_access.conditions: Exemptions must be record-specific, not categorical
rights_of_access.implementation_notes: Cannot claim 'all emails are exempt' or 'all personnel files are exempt' - must review each record individually
rights_of_access.request_tips: Challenge blanket denials: 'RCW 42.56.210 prohibits blanket exemptions. Each record must be individually reviewed and specific exemptions applied.'

rights_of_access.description: For large requests, agencies may require advance payment, but only after providing detailed cost estimate and allowing requester opportunity to modify request to reduce costs.
rights_of_access.conditions: Must provide itemized estimate; must allow request modification; prepayment only for substantial costs
rights_of_access.implementation_notes: This prevents surprise bills while protecting agencies from non-payment - requesters can adjust scope if costs too high
rights_of_access.request_tips: If advance payment required: 'Provide itemized estimate per RCW 42.56.120. I may modify request to reduce costs before agreeing to prepayment.'

rights_of_access.description: While daily penalties are available, courts may reduce penalties if agency acted in good faith attempting to comply. This encourages good faith efforts even if agency makes mistakes.
rights_of_access.conditions: Penalty reduction at court discretion based on agency good faith efforts
rights_of_access.implementation_notes: Agencies that make genuine efforts to comply may receive reduced penalties even if they initially erred
rights_of_access.request_tips: For agencies trying to comply: 'While penalties may apply, RCW 42.56.565 allows reduction for good faith efforts. Demonstrate good faith by providing access now.'

rights_of_access.subcategory: Attorney General Review for State Agencies
rights_of_access.description: State agencies (but not local) may request Attorney General review of whether records are exempt before denying. AG provides written opinion on exemption claims.
rights_of_access.conditions: Available only to state agencies; AG reviews as promptly as possible; opinions are persuasive but not binding
rights_of_access.implementation_notes: AG review can resolve close exemption questions and provide authoritative guidance, potentially avoiding litigation
rights_of_access.request_tips: For state agencies: 'If unsure about exemption application, RCW 42.56.570 allows AG review. Please request AG opinion rather than denying without certainty.'

rights_of_access.description: Some agencies must report statistics on records requests received, response times, and cost recovery. This data may be publicly available and helps requesters understand agency practices.
rights_of_access.conditions: Required for specified agencies
rights_of_access.implementation_notes: Request statistics can show how agency handles similar requests and typical fees charged
rights_of_access.request_tips: Ask: 'Do you maintain request statistics? This would help me understand typical processing times and fees for similar requests.'
